body_content.explanation: a person, organization, etc. that goes back to an activity they did earlier:
examples: The state's labour markets had been flooded by both new entrants and re-entrants into the labour force.
The chess festival attracted over 1,000 participants, including 89 reentrants, who are allowed, if dissatisfied with their start, to pay to begin the tournament again.

body_content.explanation: (of a computer program or code) able to be run on several processors at the same time and be interrupted and called again without affecting what is happening on the other processors :
examples: Re-entrant subprograms are useful in multi-threaded situations, since multiple threads can call the same subprogram without fear of interfering with each other.
When a program is executing reentrant code, another program can interrupt the execution and can then start or continue execution of that same code.
There was greater erosion of the tips of the teeth and discoloration spread into the re-entrant angles of the teeth.
The twinning is clearly shown by reentrant angles formed by equivalent faces of the two crystals where they meet.
A reentrant recess extends upwards into the coupling part around the hub.
